greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of divisible pairs of consecutive divisors of n.
comment: The number m = 2^n, n >= 0, is the smallest for which a(m) = n. - _Marius A. Burtea_, Nov 20 2019
formula: a(p^k) = k for any prime number p and k >= 0. - _Rémy Sigrist_, Oct 05 2019
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(d=divisors(n), nb=0); for (i=2, #d, if ((d[i] % d[i-1]) == 0, nb++)); nb;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Oct 05 2019
(MAGMA) f:=func<n,i|D[i+1] mod D[i] eq 0 where D is Divisors(n) >;  g:=func<k| #[i:i in [1..#Divisors(k)-1]| f(k,i)]>; [g(n):n in [1..100]]; // _Marius A. Burtea_, Nov 20 2019
xref: Successive pairs of consecutive divisors are counted by A129308.
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Oct 03 2019
